conclusion: The rod of mass 17 g (0.017 kg) placed in the uniform field experiences its weight mg downward, a supporting force from the two rails and an ampere (magnetic) force F that is horizontal and perpendicular to the rod, produced by the current I in the rod.
The rod is arranged so the two rails make 30° with the horizontal.

Resolving forces along directions perpendicular / parallel to the rod gives the equilibrium requirement: the horizontal component of the magnetic force must balance the component of the weight that tends to make the rod slide.
Because the rails make 30° with the horizontal, the component of the rod’s weight along the rail is mg sin 30° = 0.017 kg × 10 m s⁻² × 0.5 = 0.085 N.

The magnetic force, which is perpendicular to the rod and therefore horizontal, must supply an equal and opposite component along the rail. Therefore the magnitude of the ampere force is F = mg sin 30° / cos 30° = 0.085 N / 0.866 ≈ 0.10 N.
For a straight conductor of length L in a field B, F = BIL.
The length of rod between rails equals the separation of rails, 15 cm = 0.15 m.
The circuit contains the rod’s own resistance R₁ = 4 Ω, the rheostat R₂ (unknown) and the source internal resistance r = 1 Ω in series.
Total resistance required for 1.1 A from a 10 V source is R_total = E / I = 10 V / 1.1 A ≈ 9 Ω.
Hence R₁ + R₂ + r = 9 Ω ⇒ 4 Ω + R₂ + 1 Ω = 9 Ω ⇒ R₂ ≈ 4 Ω.
Ampere force on the rod: F ≈ 0.1 N
